turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Florida against Royer.
Mr. Fox, I think you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court, this is a petition to review the decision of the Florida Third District Court of Appeal in which the Florida Third District Court of Appeal reversed both the appellate panel and the trial court upon their denial of the defendant's motion to suppress.
The facts are extremely simple.
The defendant was arrested at the Miami International Airport carrying 65 pounds of marijuana in his luggage.

The state's witness, Detective Johnson, an experienced narcotics officer, testified generally as to his training and profile, so-called A, so-called D, a profile, and the fact that he observed thousands of passengers each week at the Miami International Airport eight hours a day, five days a week.
On January 3rd, 1978, about noon, the defendant appeared at the airport.
Detective Johnson testified that in his experience and Detective Magdalena's experience, it was undeniable that the defendant's conduct and demeanor attracted their attention.

The defendant was extremely nervous, pale, uneasy, looking about, and Detective Johnson testified that in his experience, the defendant was not a so-called white knuckled flier, but rather was concerned about being detected.
The bags the defendant was carrying were very heavy.
He had produced an extremely large roll of cash to pay for his ticket.
The defendant was observed placing on the airline identification labels the name of Holt, and his ticket apparently was also in that name also.
It was undisputed below--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: That was on his baggage, you said?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When did the officer find out that he bought a one-way ticket, if that was the case?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: When they examined his ticket and license upon request at the initial encounter with the defendant, Your Honor.
It was undisputed, as a matter of fact, including through the defendant's testimony, that they approached him and asked him if he had a moment to talk, and he said, fine.
The defendant himself testified that upon request--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did they identify themselves at that time?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, they identified themselves as narcotics officers, and said, may we speak with you a moment.
The defendant himself testified that he voluntarily produced his ticket and his license for their examination.
They immediately noticed the discrepancy between his ticket and the baggage and the license, and he explained that someone else had made the reservation for him.
Johnson then told the defendant that they believed that he was carrying narcotics, and would he come to a room a few feet away for further discussion.
Johnson said the defendant was thoroughly cooperative throughout the transaction.
The detectives were in plain clothes.
They displayed no insignia.
They carried weapons but they were concealed.
They did not... There is no showing in this record that they blocked his path in any way.
They were courteous at all times.
They did not threaten--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So what did he say when they asked him?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --He followed them to the room.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He didn't say anything?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: He did not say anything.
He went with the room to them.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, did they indicate that he didn't need to go, or not?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
There is not a Mendenhall type warning, if you will, in this circumstance.
The defendant proceeded to the room, as did Sylvia Mendenhall, without discussion.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Who had possession of the ticket?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: The ticket was in... evidently was in Detective Johnson's possession at all times, but it was never taken out of the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Once it was handed over.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Once it was handed over.
Did he hand it to the police?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Yes, but the ticket actually never left the defendant's possession.
It was always right there with him, with Detective Johnson, as they were carrying out the discussion, and as they went to the adjacent room.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Wait a minute.
You said never left his possession.
I thought he handed it to the detective.
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Never left his presence.
Excuse me, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it was in the possession of the detective.
Is that not correct?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So if he wanted to get on the airplane, he would have had a little difficulty.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: He would first of all have to ask to get the ticket back.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For his ticket back.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: That's correct, which he did not do in this case, of course, but there was also, as an indication of the nature of the transaction, the defendant indicated himself that he understood all that was going on, and there was no physical contact at any time.

Detective Johnson, I think important to this Court's consideration here, testified that he wanted to go to the adjacent room to avoid any embarrassment to the defendant and to avoid any possible violence in the crowded airport area.

In the room, which was 40 feet away, they again asked him if they could... they initially asked him for his consent to open his suitcase, and they told him again that they suspected him of transporting narcotics.
In response, the defendant produced a key, unlocked one of the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Fox, let me ask you another question.
You mentioned the violence concern that the officer expressed.
Do you think the facts that were known to the officer at the time he requested the ticket would have justified a frisk of the passenger for weapons?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
I think in view of the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Did the officer frisk the passenger?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
I think in view of the extremely agitated condition of the defendant, I think a frisk would have been appropriate, but it was not done.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He was carrying two suitcases, was he?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, two suitcases.
Onof the suitcases, he had the key.
He unlocked it.
The other suitcase, he did not have he key, but he said that they could go ahead and open it if they wanted to, and thereupon they opened it, and it contained the marijuana.
The entire transaction took ten to fifteen minutes.
The initial approach took a matter of only a few minutes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suppose when they first stopped him he had said no, I don't particularly care to talk to you, I don't particularly care to identify myself, or hand you over my ticket?
Would he have been free to go?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Detective Johnson specifically testified that when people refused to talk to them, that if they don't have enough facts, they let them go.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if he had said, when they asked him to go into the other room, he had said, no, I don't want to, the testimony is, they would have let him go?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So he gets to the room, and they say, may we search your suitcase, and he says, no, you may not.
What is the testimony about that?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --There is no indication one way or the other, Your Honor.
Now, I was--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did the officers at any time tell him that he was free to go?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, there was no specific advisement.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did they also tell him that he was free not to turn his ticket loose?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor, they did not specifically advise him of that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And did they also tell him he didn't have to go to the room with them?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor, they did not specifically advise him of that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They didn't tell him any of the no's, did they?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor, they did not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They only told him the do's.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Well, they asked him that, these questions, Your Honor, and the trial court accepted that as a matter of fact, that in fact the transaction was totally voluntary.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you have two armed men who say, would you mind coming along with me.
0 [Generallaughter.]
Is there any evidence that he knew that they were armed?
And, I mean, how many people do you know wouldn't go?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Your Honor, I certainly wouldn't have gone.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you go?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You wouldn't go?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: With two armed men?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: I didn't know... I would not have known they were armed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Have you ever tried it?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Have you ever tried it?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: I have been to the airport and made observations of couriers.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: These officers were in plain clothes, weren't they?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the fact that they were armed wasn't immediately evident.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: It was not immediately--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I don't see how you can miss it.
But they did say they were narcotics agents.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Unarmed.
And unarmed, that is rather rare, isn't it?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If you had been accosted by two narcotics agents who identified themselves, would you assume they were armed or not?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Your Honor, I probably would assume they were armed.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, go ahead.
Well, isn't it also true they showed them their badge?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And they also said they had been expecting him, didn't they?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
That was the defendant's testimony.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh, I see.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: That was not accepted by the trial court in this case.

Your Honor, with respect to the voluntary nature of this transaction, which seems to be the Court's concern, we would submit that there was evidence which the trial court chose to believe in this case that the transaction was a voluntary transaction.
The defendant was a 22-year-old college educated college graduate.
He had a degree in communications.
The detectives approached him, asked him if he had a moment to talk.
The defendant voluntarily produced his identification and ticket.
He was asked if he would accompany them to a room a few feet away.
He was asked if he would consent to the search.
The defendant produced a key for one bag, and said it was all right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The difficulty with that submission is that the state courts found that he was detained against his will.
They found he was arrested.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: The state court certainly did, but--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Must we overturn that to relieve you of this judgment?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --The panel decision in the trial court did not find that he was arrested, Your Honor.
What we are asking the Court to do is reinstate the panel decision and withdraw corresponding--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know, but we have to disagree with the Florida Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Absolutely, Your Honor.
I think--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They made a finding based on the record, I guess.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --They made a finding based upon the fact that his luggage had been detained and--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, whatever it was, you do say, turn that conclusion over.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --This was in no means an arrest, Your Honor.
That is what the Florida Third District en banc held, that it was an arrest.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What precisely does the holding that something was an arrest mean?
Is that basically a factual issue or a legal issue, or is it a mixed question of fact and law?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: It is a mixed question based upon the facts presented.
We would submit--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Does it imply a determination by whoever is making the finding that subjectively the person felt he was not free to go, or that objectively a reasonable person in his position would not have felt free to go, which of those two?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --I think objectively, the reasonable person innocent of crime is the standard which this Court has articulated.
In particular, Your Honor, the defendant himself said in the room that he was not under arrest.
I think that totally belies the Third District Court of Appeals conclusion that he was under arrest.

In particular, we would point to the fact that the numerous reasons announced by the Third District Court of Appeals as reasons for the arrest were not thought of or dreamed up by anybody in the trial court.
In fact, the argument in the motion to suppress, the defendant said he did what he did because they were police officers.
That is the only reason he offered whatsoever.
He offered no other reason for the detention which he claimed.
We are here years later arguing matters which the trier of fact, the defendant, and the police officers never thought of.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But, Mr. Fox, just to interrupt for a moment, what is the court that we should look to for the facts, the trial court or the appellate court?
It is a state court, and I suppose we have a limited right to disagree with them on the facts, and the appellate court did say he was in fact not free to leave.
They said that unequivocally.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: The en banc court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are we bound by that?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I think the record in the trial court is what we are bound by here, as a matter of fact.
I think there was another thing that was determined by the Third District Court of Appeal en banc.
They kept calling it the police room.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What standard of review do we follow in deciding whether or not a state appellate court was wrong in disagreeing with the state trial court on the facts?
Is it clearly erroneous, or substantial evidence, or what is the standard we should apply?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: I think that if there is substantial evidence in the trial court to base... for the trial court to have reached the conclusion that this was a voluntary transaction, that that must be flagrantly erroneous, it must be clearly erroneous, and must be a substantial departure from the constitutional law of this Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why?
Must a state have... must a state appellate court have some standard about overruling its trial courts?
What standard does the Constitution require?
Here surely the Florida appellate court overruled the district court.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Well, that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It may be that if it applied the wrong legal standard in adjudicating the federal constitutional question, we could certainly correct that, and even if it didn't apply the right... even if it applied the right standard, we could disagree with it if it is a mixed question of fact and law.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Absolutely, Your Honor, and we have argued vigorously in our brief that the standard here is, as this Court found in Mendenhall, is that the circuit court of appeal was totally mistaken in substituting its judgment for that of the trier of fact as to the issues of fact before the trial court, and that is--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeals of Florida have anything before it that we haven't before us in this case now?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Didn't it have a concession that the state made at the oral argument before that court which they refer to that the state conceded at oral argument that the officers would not have permitted Royer to leave?
We don't have that before us, but they had it before them.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: You have my offer in the brief, Your Honor, that in fact after an extensive argument with Judge Schwartz, I stated to him that in fact I wasn't there, I don't know what the officers would have done.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Are you telling us there was no such concession?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: There was a concession, but the concession was qualified in a certain context, and that context was that in fact if--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What I am suggesting to you is, we have something different before us than they had before them.
They heard your argument there.
We didn't.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, they do... they did, but I don't think... I don't think the concession is a dispositive issue in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: I think that the officers would not have let him leave, Your Honor.
I don't think that is... speculating what they might have done is not the issue.
The question is what did they do.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And you think the issue is what a reasonable person would have thought about whether he was free to leave?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Innocent of crime.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The officers may have decided in their own minds, we will never let him go, but a reasonable person might have thought that he was free to go.
Is that your argument?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Certainly it could be a voluntary transaction, irrespective as to the officer's intent in the case.

They proceeded on the basis that it was a voluntary transaction, and Your Honors, I think at the point where the defendant said, no, I don't want to give you consent to look in my suitcase, and I want to leave, I think that circumstance is a different circumstance than what transpired here.
At that point, the officers would have had to make a decision as to whether or not they could detain the defendant within the meaning of the Constitution, but they never reached that point.

That's why my concession, which is put in the footnote in the Third District Court of Appeal, if we accept the concession as it is stated facially, which I say is absolutely incorrect, and not in proper context, that concession does not affect the outcome here.
The question is what the record shows as to what transpired in the... between the--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then the only reason we disregard this finding of the court that you did make a concession is that you deny it here?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
That is not correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what else do we have?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: I have only offered my statement of the context of that remark.
That is, I stated, if the defendant had refused consent, then the officer--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What other reason do you have for us to disregard it?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Because it's not relevant to a determination of the constitutional issues here, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the en banc court did find that the defendant was under the reasonable impression that he was not free to leave, not just a subjective impression, but on the objective facts, he was under a reasonable impression that he was not free to leave.
So that in order to find for you, we must disagree with that mixed question of law and fact.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: I... My analysis of the Third District Court of Appeal decision is that they... the en banc decision, that is, that they flatly decided that because his luggage had been detained, and that because his ticket was still in the possession of Johnson, that in fact those factors created a situation where he was not free to leave as a matter of law.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he was under the reasonable... as a matter of law, he was under the reasonable impression he was not free to leave.
That is what they said.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Flatly because of those factors.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Fox, could you turn to Page... if you have it before you, Page 49 of the supplemental appendix, which I think contains the opinion of the D.C.... or perhaps you are familiar enough.
I just wanted to read you one sentence which I think is what the DCA said about this thing.
Do you call them DCA's in Florida?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, District Court of Appeal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The court said,
"Applying the test adopted in Frost, it is obvious that Royer, as he himself testified, was under the reasonable impression that he was not free to leave the presence of the officers. "
and then I guess it is a cite to the Frost opinion.
Now, why did they incorporate the test adopted in Frost in what would otherwise appear to be pretty much of a factual finding?
Did Frost say something about when you would find that someone was under a reasonable impression?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Frost went off and said, as a matter of law, when you keep a defendant's ticket, he is absolutely detained.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So they were simply applying Frost to this situation?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: They were applying that ruling in Frost.
Frost went on and made a number of other rulings, but they were applying that... that is the single factor which they say... as a matter of law, you are detained.
Now, that conflicts with Elmore, and Elmore just flatly says, just because the officer has gotten the ticket does not mean you are detained.

You are not detained until he leaves your presence with that ticket, and Elmore is the leading case in the Fifth Circuit, and Frost absolutely disregarded and severely criticized the Elmore court, which was brought to its attention.
That holding was brought to its attention.
I would like to reserve some time for rebuttal.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Frey.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, this case has several issues in it that are of great importance doctrinally to Fourth Amendment law and to federal law enforcement.

If you analyze the sequence of events that arose here, you begin with the initial contact between the agents and Mr. Royer, and there is an issue whether at that point you had a seizure of his person within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment or simply a contact not regulated by the Fourth Amendment.

That issue is important because if you had a seizure, you can consider in the effort to justify that seizure only the facts known to the agents at the time they first approached Mr. Royer, and not facts that they learned during the initial interview with him.

Now, when the situs of the transaction moved from the concourse to the office nearby, you have a question whether that movement was either fully voluntary and not subject to the Fourth Amendment, as was said in Mendenhall, or a continuation of an investigative detention, or an arrest requiring probable cause.
Now, I would like to turn first to the arrest issue, because I believe that is what the state court rested on.
There is, of course, a final issue as to whether the consent to the search of the suitcases was voluntary.
I won't address that.
I don't think it was decided by the lower court.
The rationale of the lower court was a fruits rationale, that even if the consent was voluntary, it was the product of an antecedent illegal seizure of Mr. Royer's person.
Now, I think it is crystal clear that the lower court used the wrong test in identifying whether Mr. Royer was under arrest at the time he was moved to the office and the consent was secured.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are talking about the court of appeals?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: The District Court of Appeal, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: En banc?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: En banc.
The opinion that is under review here.
That opinion suggests that the criterion for determining whether there was an arrest requiring probable cause is whether the suspect was free to leave.
As we have indicated in our brief--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought that it said whether he reasonably believed he was free--

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Well, if he reasonably believed he was free to leave, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Well, that is quite different.
That is quite different.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, not for my point.
I absolutely agree that the test is an objective one, and not his subjective belief or the subjective intentions of the officer.

But the point that I am making here is that the test of free to leave is a test that distinguishes not arrests from non-arrests, but Fourth Amendment seizures from non-seizures, and it is well settled that Fourth Amendment seizures consist of two kinds of things, the Terry type investigative detention or an arrest.
One can be based on reasonable suspicion not amounting to probable cause; the latter requires probable cause.
Now, in deciding whether what happened here was an arrest, it seems to me that it strains the English language and the logical structure of Fourth Amendment analysis to call this an arrest.

If you view these events as occurring to an innocent traveler who has mistakenly been seized upon as a possible drug courier by the agents, it would be quite clear to that person that he had not yet been arrested, that he was being detained for a brief course of investigation which would result in his release if he knew he was innocent after the officers looked in the luggage.
It did not have the indicia of duration.
If you compare it to Dunaway, you are talking about moving him a number of miles to the police station, keeping him for an indefinite period until he confessed.

From the standpoint of Mr. Dunaway, even if he were innocent, he would have perceived what happened to him, I think, quite clearly as being... having the essential attributes of a formal arrest, which is the language the Court used last term in Michigan against Summers.

Now, it is important in our view not to place undue emphasis in defining an arrest on the factors that the lower court here, the en banc court relied upon, which is movement or detention or extended custody beyond a momentary stop, because those factors may arise in many contexts where we believe that they can be legitimately done as part of an investigative detention, for instance, the detention of a suspected robber near the scene of the robbery and the question whether he could be moved, let's say, a block to the scene of the robbery for purposes of a show-up without having probable cause.
Now, let me say finally on the arrest issue that if you don't say this was not an arrest, that does not leave the subject of investigative detentions unregulated under the Fourth Amendment.

An investigative detention, like an arrest, must be reasonable, and you have the ability to say in this case that the detention under the circumstances may have been unreasonable, but calling it an arrest, I think, would be most unfortunate.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Frey, may I just ask you one question?
You say the court used the wrong test in the free to leave business for an arrest.
How would you phrase the test of an arrest?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, I think that is a difficult question.
We know what a formal arrest is, but I think--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, if that is the wrong test, you ought to know what the right test is.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Well, I don't have to.
I can know what it isn't when I don't see it--
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you don't have something--

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --without knowing necessarily exactly what--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --You don't have a test to propose to us that is better?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Well, I think what you would look at is the duration and the reasonable understanding of the individual as to whether he is likely to be charged with a crime or held for an indefinite period until he is presented--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, under that test, if one believed the testimony that the man said... he must have thought he was going to be charged with a crime, didn't he?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --He couldn't have thought... well, I think it is very important that you look at it from the perspective of an innocent person, because the purpose of these rules is to protect against innocent people being mistakenly seized upon and imposed upon by police officers.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so an innocent person who is just patient and knows if he waits out several hours, say, in the room--

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Oh, we are not--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --he knows he will get free eventually.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Well, the purpose of what... what occurred here, which took about ten to fifteen minutes, was to secure his consent and then carry out on the basis of his consent the examination of his luggage.
If it had turned up nothing, he clearly would have been released.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Arrest turns on what happens after the investigation is over?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: But the suspect would know what would happen.
That is, that he would give his consent.
There is nothing in this situation--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In other words, it all... so you are backing into a corner where it is the suspect's state of mind that determines whether the officer's conduct constitutes an arrest, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --It is not his subjective state of mind.
It is what a reasonable person in his situation would perceive based on the officer's conduct.
I think that is very important.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You apparently agree that there was a seizure, then.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or at least you say that if you accept the trial court or the court of appeal's finding, at least there was a seizure.
There may not have been an arrest.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --I... Well, let me say this.
We strongly disagree that there was a seizure at the point of initial contact.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, all right, but you do agree that at least it is the right test for the seizure, if a person--

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: The test for whether there is a seizure is whether the person reasonably believes that he is free to leave.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --That is the right test for seizure.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: And in the circumstance, I think it is very important in the circumstance in which there is no clarification either by a statement from the officer or an inquiry from--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you wouldn't state that even if... if there was a seizure here, under the right test, and you haven't said there wasn't yet, you wouldn't think that would give the officers ipso facto the right to search his luggage.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Certainly not.
The search has to be based on a consent.
The issue in this case is whether the consent was the fruit of an illegal seizure.
Our position is that if at the time they moved him to the office he had been seized, they had ample, reasonable suspicion--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's just assume everybody agreed there was a valid Terry stop.
There is a quick frisk, and the fellow says, I want to ask you a question.
May I search your luggage?
The fellow says, sure, and right on the spot, right then, in 30 seconds, the luggage is searched.
You say that, A, there is a seizure, but B, it is a completely consensual search.
That is your--

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --The search would have to be consensual in that case because there was no warrant.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Yes, and your only difference is that they... instead of searching him on the spot, they moved him into another room.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We are saying that that does not convert what would otherwise be a valid--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it certainly extends the seizure, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --It is a somewhat extended seizure beyond--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And have we ever approved that kind of seizure?
Mendenhall.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Michigan against Summers.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And Summers?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Michigan against Summers.

Not really in Mendenhall, because Mendenhall rested on a consent rationale, but in Summers quite clearly there was an extended seizure of, I think, quite considerably longer duration than this, which involved moving him a distance equal, I assume, to the distance that he was moved in this case.
So I don't think that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but that was incident to the issue of the warrant.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --But the court's discussion first--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And here's a person who came out of the house that was about to be searched.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --I understand, but if you look at the court's analysis, the court begins by creating an analytical framework within which the issue is to be decided.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There is nothing like that here.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We have exactly like that.
We have a reasonable suspicion justifying an investigative detention, an investigative detention--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, no one is... we don't have any cases justifying this long of an investigative detention.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Well, I am not sure what that... I think that the detention in Summers was investigative.
They were... the execution of the warrant was an investigation, and it was an investigation which as it happened--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but it was at least authorized by a warrant, which is the whole argument here--

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --Well, there is nothing in the warrant that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --that there was no warrant for the search of the luggage.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: --The warrant did not authorize the detention of Summers.
I see my time has expired.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Klein.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, Mr. Royer was walking in the airport, he was stopped by the police, told that they suspected him of carrying drugs.
He was moved into a converted storage closet.
They keep his tickets.
They get his bags without his consent.
He is told by the police that they would like to look in his bags to either confirm or dispel their suspicions, and he opens the bags.
Under those circumstances--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: When you say he--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --The officer opens the bags.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --With the consent of your client.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
We do not contend that there was any consent whatsoever in this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How did he get the key?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, the exact words of the agent when questioned about this issue of consent was, we told them we suspected him of carrying narcotics, and we asked him to open the bags to either confirm or dispel our suspicions.
Mr. Royer, without saying a word, took his key out of the bag... out of his pocket, opened the bag, unlocked it, and then the officer actually did the opening of the bag.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you say that was not voluntary?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say that was--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: We say that it was not voluntary, Your Honor.
We say... our position basically under these circumstances is that--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --Don't you think he could have said, you can open my bag when you get a warrant?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, he could have said very many things.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: He could have said a number of things.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --I am just posing one to you.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I am just posing one hypothetical, not many.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: All right, Your Honor.
If he had said that, then I think that there would be no consent at all, if he said you can open my bags when you get a warrant.
I think that would be quite clear that there would be no consent whatsoever under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then we don't know what would have happened, whether he would have been detained while they went to get a warrant, or whether they would have opened it without a warrant.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, we can go on the basis of either the state's concession at oral argument or as they now--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The state's concession isn't evidence in the case.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, but I think that the state's argument that is set forth in their reply brief points out specifically on Page 9, it said, what would have... what would have happened after that is that certainly in that event the officers could have readily sought other means of gathering information, including the use of a trained narcotics dog.

So I think that their basic argument is that irrespective of whether or not the consent was ultimately granted, then this individual was not going anywhere until the police had completed their investigation.

Now, we maintain that either this situation represents the most expansive Terry stop that has ever been recognized, and possibly the most coercive consent that could ever be validated, or, as we say, that it was an illegal arrest, and regardless of the nomenclature, it was tantamount to an arrest--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Klein--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: --at what point in time did the arrest become illegal?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, it is impossible to say at the precise moment when it occurred.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you agree there was reasonable suspicion to ask questions?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, I would concede that there was reasonable suspicion for the officers to approach the defendant in the airport and to engage in a contact, and nothing more.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: What do you mean by a contact?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: A contact is a voluntary encounter, as the Court pointed out in the footnotes in Terry, and all of its progeny, it is a voluntary encounter.
The police are not isolated from citizenry.
They are permitted to talk to them and to go and engage and to see whether or not there is something that arouses their suspicions any further.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: So there was a limited Terry type stop or seizure up to what point?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, we maintain that there was a limited encounter that took place in the form of the conversation, and then beyond that I think that it is unreasonable to say that anybody who is approached by officers in a public place, regardless of whether they are guilty or they are innocent, and the standard is an innocent person, we maintain that an innocent person who is asked by officers to please show his driver's license and his ticket, that it is unreasonable for--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think the conversation became unlawful at the moment the request was made to see the driver's license?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, we maintain that at the point that they asked for... at the point that he was asked for his driver's license and his ticket, at that juncture a reasonable person would not feel that they were free to walk away.
It is natural for an individual, whether they are guilty or they are innocent, when they are approached by a police officer, to produce those documents.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Klein, in the Summers decision that has been mentioned, it is perfectly clear that the individual there was not free to walk away.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The rationale of that case, as I understood it, was that under circumstances that create a reasonable suspicion, the officers may detain an individual for a period of time.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you agree with that or not?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, Michigan versus Summers was a highly limited situation, and I think that the underlying rationale there was that the issue of probable cause had already been submitted to a neutral, detached magistrate.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Probable cause to detain the individual outside of his home?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

It was probable cause for the search of the house, and under those circumstances, a limited seizure detention of the individual was appropriate in order to ascertain if there was going to be any evidence that was turned up in the house.
But I don't think the Michigan versus Summers reflects the proper model for determination of the issues here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Who was the person detained in that case?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: It was the owner of the house.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that house was covered by a search warrant?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: That's correct, and that was really the underlying rationale, that a neutral, detached magistrate had issued a search warrant, and I think the Court made it quite clear that that function should be served by someone in that position rather than those who are on the front line such as police who are often engaged in the competitive aspects of ferreting out crime.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Refresh my recollection, Mr. Klein.
Did the Court in Sumner rely on Terry?
That was my recollection.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, it was a Terry extension.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: A Terry type limited seizure, was my recollection.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, it was a Terry type limited seizure.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: But it was based upon the rationale of a neutral magistrate already having secured a warrant, and I think that that is the way that that can be justified under those circumstances, and it was justified on the basis that it was necessary in order to determine whether or not there was any individual or any proof that might turn up during the course of the search itself, which is far more intrusive in and of itself than the seizure of the individual.
Now, what our position is is that whatever Terry stop may have been justified in the first instance in this matter became increasingly more custodial and ultimately culminated in an illegal arrest.
The traditional dividing point has always been, of course, probable cause.
The Terry case recognized an intermediate step which was limited in nature and in purpose.
It is between the contact and an arrest.

Articulable suspicion permits a limited seizure of the person, but it must be done with the clear caveat that whatever intrusion takes place pursuant to this seizure must be limited to that which made its initiation permissible in the first place.
So that asking a seized driver to get out of his car for the immediate safety of the officer has been upheld.
A patdown, as in Terry, has been upheld.

In Fuenta, Martinez, Martinez Fuenta, border stop inquiry with reference to immigration status has been upheld, but none of those cases and none of the Terry line of cases have expanded the intermediate step to the extreme here without either requiring probable cause or calling it an arrest.
So therefore the real question is, is what happened here, up to the actual point of the search of the luggage, can it be justified as a Terry stop.
Now, first of all, I think it is important to distinguish this case from the Mendenhall--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could I ask you what I asked your colleague?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: A voluntary stop, even, you would say that is a voluntary stop, a quick patdown and one question, may I search your luggage.
The man says yes.
The luggage is searched.
Wouldn't the only question be the question whether the consent was voluntary?
You wouldn't say--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I would have no problem with that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --And you wouldn't say that just because there was a seizure, a momentary seizure under Terry, that his consent to search would be an invalid fruit?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I would have no problem with that whatsoever.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you think that... Let's assume there was a valid Terry stop here initially.
Just assume that.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If they had then asked him, may we search your luggage, and he said yes, and they searched it right on the spot, no problem.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I have no problem with that whatsoever.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is just the movement into the other room?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Even under certain circumstances, a movement may be appropriate, but it was the combination of factors here.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: A movement could be a lot less embarrassing.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, that is true, but if that is the case, then every time that the police conduct a so-called Terry stop, and they want to avoid embarrassment to the subject of the Terry stop, that would in their rationale permit them to move him off to some isolated place.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then what?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: And then conduct whatever it is that they want to do.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is it just the lapse of time, or is it the change of atmosphere which makes it reasonable for somebody to think that he is still being detained?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, the lapse of time is only one factor, and I don't think this is critical in this case.
The lapse of time has been held to be a long time to be reasonable.
In Michigan versus Summers, two hours was reasonable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But let's concede there was an initial seizure, as in my example.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: A Terry stop and seizure, and then he is just moved somewhere, and they ask him, may we search your luggage, and he says yes.
That consent then is bad, although it wouldn't have been--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I'm sorry, I didn't follow.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --A voluntary stop initially--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --and a seizure, and they take him away to another place, and five minutes later they ask him, may we search your luggage, and he says yes.
You think that is necessarily a fruit of an arrest?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --I'm sorry, I didn't quite follow the question.
If there is an initial Terry stop--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if he can consent to searching his luggage initially--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --under a valid stop, why can't he validly consent to it five minutes later?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: He could, if the circumstances were right.
If they hadn't engaged in any more coercive conduct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Like what?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Like taking his ticket, as they did here.

Like going and getting his bags and putting them in the room, isolating him, as they did here, advising him, now, we suspect you under these circumstances of carrying narcotics, we would like you to open the bag to see whether or not there is anything in there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that makes it more likely that he would consent to searching his bags?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I think it would, Your Honor.
I think that placing him in that kind of a coercive atmosphere makes it more likely.

I think it is unreasonable after an individual such as this has been removed to a room, they've gotten his bags, they've gotten his ticket, they tell him, now, we suspect you of carrying narcotics, and we would like you to open up the bag in order to confirm or dispel our suspicions, I think it is unreasonable to think that anybody, guilty or innocent, can simply say, well, I've had quite enough of this, gentlemen, I've got to go on my way.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is your conclusion then that his consent is coerced, or that there is an arrest and a fruit of an invalid arrest?
That is a completely different thing.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, it's both.
It's both.
I haven't gotten to the consent--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you don't need to get to the arrest then.
It is just a coerced--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --We don't have to.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --It's just a coerced consent.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I believe that it is.

I think that that would be the easiest way to decide this, is that this was a coerced consent under the circumstances, and regardless of whether or not we call it an arrest or not, it is a clear confinement which exceeds the scope--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the court below didn't decide that.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The court below said there was an arrest and a fruit of an invalid arrest.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, I think that the exact--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't that what it said?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, I think that the exact holding of the court--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, they said there was an arrest.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --They said that regardless of the exact nomenclature employed to describe this situation, it is unimportant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where are you reading from in the supplemental appendix?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I don't have the supplemental appendix.
I am reading under the section that is Consent Invalid, and then then it says... Royer Involuntarily Confined is the first section, and then the second section, Number Two, it's Page 50.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No Probable Cause?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me?
That's correct.
The section that says No Probable Cause.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It says Royer had been placed under arrest, no probable cause.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
It says,
"For all practical purposes, he had been placed under arrest when the alleged consent was given. "
"The exact nomenclature employed to describe this situation is, however, unimportant. "
I don't think that the term "arrest" should be dispositive of the situation, because of his precise situation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but we have held that even so-called voluntary consents or voluntary statements after an invalid arrest are still fruits--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --and inadmissible.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Without finding them coerced.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I agree.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is your submission here?
Is it that the consent was coerced and therefore invalid?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, the consent... there was no consent, is our position, is therefore invalid, but irrespective of that, it was a Terry stop that exceeded the scope of what is reasonably necessary.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And thereupon became an arrest.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it did, and in connection with that, the Court's inquiry of the government as to when a seizure becomes an arrest, and the government was unable to come up with a clear definition.
Well, I like the definition that the government itself gave, and that was in their brief in this case.

They advert to their brief in the Michigan versus Summers case, and on Page 10, they point out in their brief that after saying that Dunaway made it clear that the formal label is not dispositive, that
"probable cause is required whenever there is a sufficiently substantial invasion of the suspect's freedom of movement. "
"What constitutes a sufficiently substantial deprivation of liberty to require probable cause remains to be fleshed out. "

"If, however, a detention is deemed to be of sufficient severity to fall within this category, its lawfulness will not be evaluated by reference to a general reasonable analysis, but will ordinarily depend solely upon the existence of probable cause. "
That's what we have here, Your Honor.
I maintain that the Terry stop exceeded the initial reason for the intrusion.
It was unnecessary to expand it to the point that it was.
It was unnecessary under these circumstances, and therefore constitutionally unreasonable.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You indicated that you thought the initial stop was perfectly valid, the stop and the inquiry.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, it was about roughly 15 steps from where they then stood to the room.
At what point did he... you say he became under arrest?
The first step, fifth step, tenth step?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

I would say that by the time he was asked for his consent, he was under arrest, and I think that it is impossible to single out any of those crucial elements that I have adverted to, and the court, the Florida court, the appeals court did not try to distinguish between those crucial elements, and I think that the government is incorrect when they say that the sole basis of the Florida court's position about an illegal arrest was based upon his... the reasonable apprehension that he was not free to go.
That was merely one of the factors that the Florida court adverted to in making its ultimate determination that an arrest had occurred.
It specifically cited the other instances of misconduct indicating that the man was not free to go, such as the... and that he was in effect in a classic case of imprisonment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You haven't argued, unless I have missed it, that there was not even any grounds for a valid Terry stop here.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I have not as yet, but I will be glad to address that point.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that is part of your submission, I take it.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and on that particular point, what our problem is is that this is... this Terry stop was based upon the so-called profile, drug courier profile, and the government has submitted in their orange book to the Court a compilation of the law and the cases, and they point out, for one thing, that there is no national profile, and the reason for this is that a perusal of the cases that they have in their book shows that all of the elements are contradictory.
In one case, it is the last passenger off the plane.
The next time, it is the first passenger.
No bags, heavy bags, or empty bags.
Walking very fast, very slow.
A one-way ticket, a round-trip ticket.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They are always nervous.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: They are always... not always.
Sometimes nervous.
Nervousness seems to be a factor in Atlanta but not necessarily in Los Angeles.
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What point are you trying to make.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What point are you trying to make?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: The point that I am trying to make is that it is very much like analyzing why the stock market has gone up the previous day.
It permits the police to take what is essentially a hunch.
They select out the factors that fit.
They give it a label, and they mask what is essentially a hunch and essentially arbitrary action--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is arbitrary about following a hunch?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --There is nothing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I personally am not persuaded that police officers enjoy running around after red herrings or running after people who really aren't going to provide any leads or clues.

Shouldn't the courts give some deference in this situation to the considered experience of law enforcement personnel, just on the basis that they are the ones on the scene, and probably know a little bit more about it than we do?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, in some instances, that's true.
First of all, though, we are dealing with a particular case, and here, this case, the officer had all of one month's experience.
He had been on the job since November.
This was January.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but the profile was presumably devised by people other than him.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: All right.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What does the one month's experience have to do with it?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: All right, Your Honor, because we are talking about what essentially must be individualized suspicion, and a perfect example here is that some of the characteristics that were adverted to by the officer in his testimony as to why he suspected this person was because he was carrying American Tourister luggage.
He said he was carrying one old suitcase, one new suitcase, and he put them up near the counter, and most people carry their luggage with them.
Now, the profile has its place.

It is an excellent administrative tool for the police to use to single out possible suspicious activity for further investigation, but it should not be used as a justification for intruding on the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Because the fact of being part of a profile in and of itself should not be used in connection with a Terry stop as a substitute for individualized suspicion.
I think every case since Terry has talked about individualized suspicion as to why it was that a particular element in the profile was or was not--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Supposing the government could produce evidence, which I take it it hasn't here, that if each of these elements of the profile when they were run down, 70 percent of the follow-ups indicated a person who was probably guilty of some offense and 30 percent didn't.
Now, would you say that an officer couldn't simply apply that profile across the board if it were documented in that way, without making any further individualized determination?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --I still think that he needs to make an individualized determination in every instance.
I think that that sort of statistical approach--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if the individualized determination he makes was that this person whom I am following now exhibits eight of the ten characteristics that the profile says to look for, and each of those ten characteristics is documented by experience?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --I still think, Your Honor, under those circumstances, that he has to be able to articulate whether or why any particular item of behavior, regardless of whether it is on or off the profile--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Any particular item or the combination of all of them?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --He can use a combination of all of them, but he still must articulate why it is that he believes that these things lead him to suspect that a crime is being committed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why not past experience?

If 80 percent of the follow-ups in the past of people with a particular kind of luggage have indicated that you find a guilty person, why isn't that a perfectly adequate basis of using that in the case of an expert who comes along?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, I still think that under those circumstances, that there has got to be some showing that in this particular case that they suspect him of a crime, because each of those things are innocent in and of themselves.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of course, but that is a very fallacious approach of the undistributed middle, which really doesn't mean anything in this kind of situation.
You say... You keep referring to what you think and what you believe.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What cases from this Court support your view that a profile of this sort is not usable in any circumstances?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that the concurring opinion in the Mendenhall case in Footnote Number 6, Justice Powell specifically indicated that a mere profile match in and of itself would not take the substitute... it would not be a substitute for that sort of individualized suspicion.

Its appearance on the profile may or may not have significance, but the mere fact that it does appear on the profile cannot be used as a substitute to make the determination that in fact a suspicion of a crime has been committed.
There still must be something that is articulated as to why--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: On your approach, a profile has no use whatsoever.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --No, I believe that it has a very, very useful approach, to single out from the very large universe of people those whom there is some unusual activity that would cause the police then to go and conduct a further inquiry.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It worked pretty well here, didn't it?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It worked pretty well here.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Well, I think we must look at things at the point prior to the search.

Otherwise... we can't look at it afterwards as a bootstrapping sort of thing, because in every case in which there is a... a criminal case in which there is a motion to suppress, it means that it works, but the determination still must be made prior to the actual--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You were emphasizing the individual components here some time back.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It turned out that one of these suitcases weighed 65 pounds.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, they were 65 together, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Together?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: It was an aggregate.
Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That is quite a lot for two suitcases for the size indicated by this record.
