turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: They were heavy suitcases, Your Honor.
There is no doubt about it.
But the fact that somebody is carrying heavy suitcases does not give one the kind of articulable suspicion that a crime is being committed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not standing alone.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not standing alone.
But it is one of the factors, you would concede.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, it is a factor, but it still does not show why a crime has been committed.

The fact that it is American Tourister, or that it is a heavy suitcase, the fact that the person looked nervous... and by the way, there is a case that says... pointed out as one of the characteristics that the defendant looked very calm, so again, there is a contradiction to every single one of these items that occurs.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then I say again that in your position the profile is perfectly useless.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, I believe that it is very useful for the police to go and to make the initial contact so that they don't have to just select people out at random to see whether or not they are drug couriers in an airport, and at that point, then, they would go and make their contact.
Now, if the state and the government are fearful of a person getting away with crime, the police don't have to shrug their shoulders and simply walk away.
They can still limit the intrusion to the reason within the Terry standards.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are not suggesting that they have to have reasonable suspicion to go up and ask the fellow just to--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: No, I am not suggesting that at all, Your Honor.
They could do it--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --So, let's assume on these facts you applied the rationale of the plurality in Mendenhall.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where would you be then?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I'm sorry, I didn't understand.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Justice Stewart's opinion in Mendenhall.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Apply that to this case.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: If you would apply that to this case, then there would be no seizure at all in the first instance, but--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The facts aren't really different from Mendenhall, are they?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, there are.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why was there more of a seizure here than there was in Mendenhall?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: First of all, the ticket was handed back in Mendenhall.
The trial court made a specific finding in Mendenhall that Mrs. Mendenhall had agreed to go to the room in a spirit of cooperation.
She was never told--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's a finding.
I'm talking about the facts.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --All right.
She was never told either out in the concourse or in the office that she was suspected of carrying narcotics, so that there is a focus issue that is involved there.
There was no retrieval of her luggage.
She was advised in the room of her right to refuse.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's assume there was no reasonable suspicion in this case, there was just the profile, and assume we agreed with you that that doesn't amount to reasonable suspicion, but nevertheless it did sort this person out.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you go up to him, and you say, may I ask you some questions?
We are narcotics officers, and we suspect you of carrying narcotics.
We want to ask you one question.
May we search your luggage, and he says yes.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Again, I still would have--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You don't have any problem at all.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --If that took place out in the concourse, I would have no problem with it, and in fact I think that if--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, next question.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He goes up to him, we are narcotics officers, we suspect you of carrying narcotics, but we have no articulatable suspicion about that.
One question.
Would you come over and let us search your luggage in this room over here?
And he says yes.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, now we are beginning to build hypothets that I can't answer, because I think that it may or may not be.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, he doesn't say... now they just say, will you come over to this room, and he says yes, and he gets over there, and they say, may we search your luggage.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Then we are closer to a Mendenhall situation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, Justice Stewart said that is just complete consent all the way down, no seizure, no nothing.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, then perhaps we get closer to a Mendenhall situation, but that's not the situation that we have here, and I think again in order to determine--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, one of the government's arguments is that it is.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, that's correct, but I think in order to determine these issues of the scope of the Terry seizure, that we have got to go back and look at the Terry poll stars, and see what it is that is sought to be accomplished, and one of the things that must be determined is how far we can extend this Terry stop without running afoul of the original principle.

The whole object of all of the Terry cases, including the investigative stop cases, is that the scope of the intrusion must be limited to the reason for the initial seizure, and that is what justified the Terry rationale in the first place.
Now, if we limit that under these circumstances to the Terry seizure, then I think it is clear that whatever occurs should occur out there in the concourse.
It is constitutionally unreasonable to take all the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why should the test of a seizure be what the seizee reasonably thought about whether he was free to go or not?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Why should it be?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, because on that basis, you probably will never permit the police to go up to anybody and say, may I ask you a question.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, I agree, but that is what the Court has said, that that is the test, because I don't think there's any way--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why shouldn't it rest on some act of compulsion or show of force by the police?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, the cases have said the question is whether or not the "seizee" is under the reasonable belief that he was not free to walk away.
I think it's a very, very difficult rationale to apply, but nevertheless that is the standard that this Court has adopted--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In what cases was that?
What case?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, I think that it's a number of cases that follow Terry, and I think that under... I can't recall exactly which of those cases, but the question has always been stated under whether or not the seizee--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In one case, have five Justices agreed to that?
It was Justice Stewart's opinion joined by one other Justice in Mendenhall.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --All right.

My own feeling is that that is an unworkable standard, that it ought to be a standard as to whether or not... whether or not some act is done by the police officer that would reasonably indicate that the defendant was not free to go, not the subjective standard of what was in the defendant's mind, because that's an impossible standard to apply, and I think that looking at it from the standpoint of the law enforcement authorities rather than from the subjective standard of the defendant makes a lot more sense.

And looking at it from that standard, if a police officer asks an individual on the street or anywhere, can I see your license, it is unreasonable to believe that the person thinks that he can freely walk away without giving up his license or without arousing further suspicion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there is one way to find out, and that is by saying no.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, but again, we are talking about what would happen afterwards on the basis of a hypothetical.
Now, if the state and the government are fearful of a person in Mr. Royer's position getting away with crime, the police do not have to shrug their shoulders and walk away.
They can still limit the intrusion to the reason within the Terry standards and yet carry on with a number of efficacious techniques.
They can continue the brief seizure on the spot.
They can continue the questioning.
They can ask there if he would consent.
They can check with the ticket agent.
They can do a dog sniff of his luggage.
Also, they know that he's getting on a plane, and they know where he's going to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How long can they continue the questioning?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How long can they continue the questioning?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: How long?
Your Honor, I think that the standard just has to be one of whether or not it is reasonable, and I don't think that they can--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can they retain the man's ticket while they do the questioning, in your view?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --Your Honor, if it's a seizure on the spot, I think that they could retain his ticket.

That would be a means of holding him on a leash, because if there is a proper Terry seizure in the first instance, then I would think that under those circumstances it would be reasonable to hold their ticket while they are questioning him on the spot, but if they are going to attempt to remove him to some other place, then in order to expand that, they've got to have some legitimate reason why it is necessary to go to another place other than the general law enforcement objectives.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do I understand you to say, then, that if they had asked him in the terminal rather than in the office to open the bags, you'd have no objection?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I think that that would be appropriate under those circumstances.
They can ask for a consent there, but it was merely the coercive elements that inhered in the situation in this instance.
Also, they know... I started to give some reasons as to why it was that they could conduct it in another manner.
He is getting on a plane for New York, so they know very well where he is going to be for the next two and a half hours.

And the agent testified in this case that he is in constant communication with agents in every other city throughout the country, checking on passengers coming and going in these instances, so it is very easy for them to do what they have to do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: The logical result of what you say, that they could have required him to open his suitcases right on the spot--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --in your response to Justice Stevens, but because he takes 15 steps to save him some public embarrassment, then they lose some rights?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, it is not just the movement of the 15 steps.
First of all, they put him into a converted storage closet.
It could be five steps, but once they move behind a door which is only three inches wide--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You call it a closet.
How big was the room, as long as you have defined it as a closet?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: --It was defined by the police as a converted storage closet.
The Court of Appeals pointed out that the officer did testify, contrary to what the state says, that it was a police room.
It was outfitted with a desk and two chairs, and it's impossible to say.
There's nothing in the record to indicate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: A big closet.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: The size of a closet with a desk and two chairs?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: The situation would be different in your view if it were as large as this courtroom?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that that would be an element, but I don't think that it is dispositive at all.
I think that the coercive elements that all combined in this case added up to the situation that existed here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's assume that the officers said, we hereby arrest you, and then they asked--

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: It could be an illegal arrest.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Well, let's assume there was even probable cause.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And they say, may we search your suitcase, and he says yes.
There is nothing wrong with that consent necessarily, is there?

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: I would say that there is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There was probable cause.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: If there was probable cause, even... oh, if there was probable cause, no.
I would say not.
Under Schneckloth it would be an acceptable... it would be an acceptable standard.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even if the case turned on the voluntariness, it could be found completely voluntary.

turn.speaker: theodore_klein
turn.label: Mr. Theodore Klein
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, it could.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Fox, do you have anything further?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I have--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have six minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
Thank you.
First of all, Your Honor, we certainly do not abandon any arguments we raise in our extensive brief, including the good faith exception.

I would like to address why the voluntariness issue in this Court should be overturned, and that is, this Court's various holdings, and we quote United States versus Price that a finding of consent should not be overturned unless it is clearly erroneous.

The evidence in this case is not so overwhelming that either this Court or the District Court of Appeal en banc should overturn both the panel opinion and the trial court on the question of voluntariness.
The defendant just stated that this was a police room, and the witnesses so testified.
In fact, Johnson was asked,
"Is that an official police room. "
"No, it's a closet that has shelves on one end. "
"Do you have any police paraphernalia whatsoever in that room? "
"No, because it's an area that we really couldn't secure very well. "
The police room is something that the Third District called this room.
It is not something that it was in fact.

With respect to why the defendant was stopped... assuming the defendant was detained... excuse me... when he was taken to the room, he was not detained because he had American Tourister luggage, Your Honor.

He was detained because of numerous facts and circumstances, not the least of which included the profile as a written indication of the officers' experience, and particularly his efforts to avoid detection as are observed by the officers, and particularly Johnson's observations of the defendant's counter-surveillance, if you will.
Certainly, normal airline passengers don't conduct counter-surveillance to see if they are being observed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When did they discover that he was using a false name, at least a different name?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: The alias was discovered at the very moment of the initial contact with the defendant, Your Honor, and that alias, Elmore, and Partino, cited in our brief, Elmore said,
"It would be a failure of duty had the federal agents not detained Elmore at that point to investigate him further. "
Now, that is detained to investigate further, which, assuming this was a detention, that it was absolutely lawful under Elmore.
Elmore also said,
"Upon these facts, profile or no profile, the officers also had a right to ask the defendant if he would consent to the search of his luggage. "
Patino reached exactly a similar result.
With respect to the test to be applied, Your Honors, there's a two-part test here that we've argued in our brief.
First of all, Terry and Mendenhall held that there is no detention unless there is physical force or a show of authority, and neither one of those circumstances was present in this case.
The second--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Didn't they say they were officers?
Isn't that... They showed him a badge?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --That is not a show of authority, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is it a show of?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: It's a show of the officers not wanting to have a nervous courier react to the fact that he was about to be taken out in the Everglades and left in the trunk of an automobile.
These officers identify themselves for that specific reason, that the courier realizes that he is not being trailed by somebody else.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then you must not object to the word "authority".
You want to show them the authority to protect them.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: You want to show them the authority to--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You want to show them authority.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --alleviate their fear that somebody who is not lawful and who--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, do you want to show them authority or not?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --It is not a show of authority.
Merely identifying oneself as a police officer is not a show of authority.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How does an officer make a show of authority?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How does an officer make a show of authority if he doesn't by identifying himself and showing the authorization to act as an officer?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: He does it by announcing to the defendant, you stay here, some sort of announcement, some sort of indication to the defendant.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They asked him to open the baggage.
Would that be a show of authority?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Merely a request to open the bag is not a show of authority, Your Honor.
This Court has so held in Schneckloth.
If this Court accepts that announcement of identification is a show of authority, then we are out the window on the mere contact concept, which this Court accepted in Mendenhall.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your friend has conceded that they could have told him to open the bags immediately on the spot.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
His whole thing apparently rests at this point on whether or not the movement to the room is some sort of detention.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that a show of authority or an exercise of authority?

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I think it was merely a request.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there still could be a difference between asking a person, may we search your luggage, and saying to him, stay right here, now, open your luggage, we are officers.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's an order.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: That's a different circumstance.
Exactly.
That is a show of authority.
Now, the second part of the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is an exercise of coercion.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Stay right here, we are going to get a warrant, that certainly is an exercise--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, or saying, now, open your luggage, we order you to open your luggage.

turn.speaker: calvin_l_fox
turn.label: Mr. Calvin L. Fox
turn.text: --Assuming that had been held in the trial court, that would be an exercise of authority.

Your Honor, there is a second part to our analysis here as to the test to be applied in this case, and that is, there must be a balancing test between the public's interest in... the compelling public interest in law enforcement and the de minimus intrusion which is present in this case, and we would urge this Court to follow the balancing test as articulated in Michigan versus Summers.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The Honorable Court is now adjourned until tomorrow at 10:00.
